an5.75:1.1: “Mendicants, these five warriors are found in the world.
an5.75:1.3: Firstly, one warrior falters and founders at the mere sight of a cloud of dust. He doesn’t stay firm, and fails to plunge into battle.
an5.75:1.5: This is the first warrior found in the world.
an5.75:2.1: Furthermore, one warrior can prevail over a cloud of dust,
an5.75:2.2: but he falters and founders at the mere sight of a banner’s crest. He doesn’t stay firm, and fails to plunge into battle.
an5.75:2.4: This is the second warrior found in the world.
an5.75:3.1: Furthermore, one warrior can prevail over a cloud of dust and a banner’s crest,
an5.75:3.2: but he falters and founders at the mere sound of turmoil. He doesn’t stay firm, and fails to plunge into battle.
an5.75:3.4: This is the third warrior found in the world.
an5.75:4.1: Furthermore, one warrior can prevail over a cloud of dust and a banner’s crest and turmoil,
an5.75:4.2: but he’s killed or injured when blows are struck.
an5.75:4.4: This is the fourth warrior found in the world.
an5.75:5.1: Furthermore, one warrior can prevail over a cloud of dust and a banner’s crest and turmoil and being struck.
an5.75:5.2: He wins victory in battle, establishing himself as foremost in battle.
an5.75:5.4: This is the fifth warrior found in the world.
an5.75:5.5: These are the five warriors found in the world.
an5.75:6.1: In the same way, these five individuals similar to warriors are found among the monks.
an5.75:6.3: Firstly, one monk falters and founders at the mere sight of a cloud of dust. He doesn’t stay firm, and fails to keep up the spiritual life.
an5.75:6.4: Declaring his inability to continue training, he disavows it and returns to a lesser life.
an5.75:6.7: ‘In such and such a village or town there’s a women or a girl who is attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty.’
an5.75:6.8: Hearing this, he falters and founders. He doesn’t stay firm, and fails to keep up the spiritual life.
an5.75:6.9: Declaring his inability to continue training, he disavows it and returns to a lesser life.
an5.75:7.1: I say that this individual is like the warrior who falters and founders at the mere sight of a cloud of dust.
an5.75:7.4: This is the first individual similar to a warrior found among the monks.
an5.75:8.1: Furthermore, one monk can prevail over a cloud of dust,
an5.75:8.2: but at the mere sight of a banner’s crest he falters and founders. He doesn’t stay firm, and fails to keep up the spiritual life.
an5.75:8.3: Declaring his inability to continue training, he disavows it and returns to a lesser life.
an5.75:8.5: It’s when a monk doesn’t hear:
an5.75:8.6: ‘In such and such a village or town there’s a women or a girl who is attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty.’
an5.75:8.7: But he sees for himself a women or a girl who is attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty.
an5.75:8.8: Seeing her, he falters and founders. He doesn’t stay firm, and fails to keep up the spiritual life.
an5.75:8.9: Declaring his inability to continue training, he disavows it and returns to a lesser life.
an5.75:9.1: I say that this individual is like the warrior who can prevail over a cloud of dust,
an5.75:9.2: but he falters and founders at the mere sight of a banner’s crest.
an5.75:9.5: This is the second individual similar to a warrior found among the monks.
an5.75:10.1: Furthermore, one monk can prevail over a cloud of dust and a banner’s crest,
an5.75:10.2: but he falters and founders at the mere sound of turmoil. He doesn’t stay firm, and fails to keep up the spiritual life.
an5.75:10.3: Declaring his inability to continue training, he disavows it and returns to a lesser life.
an5.75:10.5: It’s when a mendicant who has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut is approached by a lady. She smiles, chats, laughs, and teases him.
an5.75:10.6: He falters and founders. He doesn’t stay firm, and fails to keep up the spiritual life.
an5.75:10.7: Declaring his inability to continue training, he disavows it and returns to a lesser life.
an5.75:11.1: I say that this individual is like the warrior who can prevail over a cloud of dust and a banner’s crest,
an5.75:11.2: but he falters and founders at the mere sound of turmoil.
an5.75:11.5: This is the third individual similar to a warrior found among the monks.
an5.75:12.1: Furthermore, one monk can prevail over a cloud of dust and a banner’s crest and turmoil,
an5.75:12.2: but he’s killed or injured when blows are struck.
an5.75:12.4: It’s when a mendicant who has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut is approached by a lady. She sits right by him, lies down, or embraces him.
an5.75:12.5: Without resigning the training and declaring his inability to continue, he indulges in sex.
an5.75:13.1: I say that this individual is like the warrior who can prevail over a cloud of dust and a banner’s crest and turmoil, but is killed or injured when blows are struck.
an5.75:13.4: This is the fourth individual similar to a warrior found among the monks.
an5.75:14.1: Furthermore, one monk can prevail over a cloud of dust and a banner’s crest and turmoil, and being struck. He wins victory in battle, establishing himself as foremost in battle.
an5.75:14.3: It’s when a mendicant who has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut is approached by a lady. She sits right by him, lies down, or embraces him.
an5.75:14.4: But he disentangles and frees himself, and goes wherever he wants.
an5.75:14.5: He frequents a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
an5.75:15.1: Gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, he sits down cross-legged, sets his body straight, and establishes mindfulness in his presence.
an5.75:15.2: Giving up covetousness for the world, he meditates with a heart rid of covetousness, cleansing the mind of covetousness.
an5.75:15.3: Giving up ill will and malevolence, he meditates with a mind rid of ill will, full of sympathy for all living beings, cleansing the mind of ill will.
an5.75:15.4: Giving up dullness and drowsiness, he meditates with a mind rid of dullness and drowsiness, perceiving light, mindful and aware, cleansing the mind of dullness and drowsiness.
an5.75:15.5: Giving up restlessness and remorse, he meditates without restlessness, his mind peaceful inside, cleansing the mind of restlessness and remorse.
an5.75:15.6: Giving up doubt, he meditates having gone beyond doubt, not undecided about skillful qualities, cleansing the mind of doubt.
an5.75:15.7: He gives up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom.
an5.75:15.8: Then, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, he enters and remains in the first absorption …
an5.75:15.9: second absorption … third absorption … fourth absorption.
an5.75:16.1: When his mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—he extends it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
an5.75:16.2: He truly understands: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
an5.75:16.3: He truly understands: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’.
an5.75:16.4: Knowing and seeing like this, his mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
an5.75:16.5: When it is freed, he knows it is freed.
an5.75:16.6: He understands: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’
an5.75:17.1: I say that this individual is like the warrior who can prevail over a cloud of dust and a banner’s crest and turmoil and being struck. He wins victory in battle, establishing himself as foremost in battle.
an5.75:17.4: This is the fifth individual similar to a warrior found among the monks.
an5.75:17.5: These five individuals similar to warriors are found among the monks.”
